Award.AwardTitle: Zoom In! Learning Science with Data

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
The Discovery Research K-12 program (DRK-12) seeks to significantly enhance the learning and teaching of science, technology, engineering and mathematics (STEM) by preK-12 students and teachers through research and development of innovative resources, models and tools. Projects in the DRK-12 program build on fundamental research in STEM education and prior research and development efforts that provide theoretical and empirical justification for proposed projects. This project will expand the DRK-12 portfolio by contributing to a limited program portfolio on data science, and also by being responsive to a broader, national discourse on data science, exemplified in the data-dependent scientific practices emphasis in the Next Generation Science Standards (NGSS). With the impetus toward data literacy, an acute need has emerged for high quality evidence-based models, practices, and tools to better prepare high school teachers to teach data skills and for students to develop the problem solving and analytical skills needed to interpret and understand data, particularly in the sciences. This project will address these challenges by leveraging novel research and design approaches, using digital tools and two well-established online instructional platforms; Zoom In and Common Online Data Analysis Platform.

With a user base of over 27,000 teachers and students, the existing Zoom In platform has proven successful in fostering evidence-based inquiry among social studies teachers. This project will test the feasibility of the platform to facilitate data-focused inquiry and skill development among high school science teachers and their students. In Year 1, two NGSS-aligned digital curriculum modules and supporting materials focused on scientific phenomena and problems in biology and earth science will be developed for high school science teachers and embedded in a modified iteration of Zoom In. The Common Online Data Analysis Platform (CODAP) will be integrated into the modules to make hierarchical data structures, modeling, visualizations, and dynamic linking possible within Zoom In. A pilot and usability test will be conducted with 16 teachers and 100 students from diverse New York City public high schools. Two teacher focus groups and think-aloud sessions with the students will be held. In Year 2, the remaining four modules will be developed. Guided by four research questions, field testing with teachers and students will be done to assess the content, CODAP data tools, Zoom-in student supports, teacher supports, and outcome measures. In Year 3, final revisions to the tools will be completed. A small-scale efficacy test will be conducted to assess aspects of the implementation process, practices, and overall impact of the modules on student learning. For the efficacy study, a two-level cluster-randomized design will be employed to randomly assign schools to the Zoom In intervention. A comparison group will use another existing well-designed data literacy digital instructional platform but without key aspects of Zoom In. Outcome measures will be administered at the beginning and end of the school year to the treatment and comparison groups. Back-end data, observational data, and teacher log data will be collected and analyzed. Qualitative data will be gathered from teacher and student observations and interviews and analyzed. Researchers will analyze the impact on student learning using hierarchical linear models with an effect treatment condition and student-and-class-level covariates. The research findings will be broadly disseminated through the Zoom In platform, conferences, publications, and social media.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Zoom In! Learning Science With Data Project Outcomes Report

Big Data now plays a powerful role in our lives, in the decisions we make in business, in social life, in politics and in science and health. The coronavirus epidemic is just one example: think how important getting good data has been in responding to the crisis. Even more, think how important it has been to communicate to the public what the data show about the spread of the virus. Yet as the Co-Vid19 example suggests, most of us are ill prepared to understand and use data and data visualizations to make decisions; we are even less prepared to query data sets in new ways, to and use data as evidence when we reason and argue about important problems. 

Today's students need a new level of data literacy, the ability to interpret, analyze and communicate about problems using data. New standards such as the Next Generation Science Standards (NGSS) call for teachers to begin developing these skills in students, but schools and teachers are not well prepared to build students' data literacy. The two most likely places in the curriculum for students to learn the basics of data science, statistics classes and science classes, do not give students experience with large data sets about important topics. At most, students are most likely to work with very small data sets (e.g. from a classmate survey or a lab experiment) and query it in very simple ways, for example by finding measures of central tendency.  Moreover, science teachers who do wish to build students' skills with large data sets face a significant barrier: authentic data sets are generally too complex and ill-structured to use in teaching. 

Zoom In: Learning Science With Data is designed as a solution. Zoom In?s online curriculum modules make it easy for high school Biology and Earth Science teachers to build their students' skill in working with authentic scientific data sets as they tackle core topics in the curriculum. Created by Education Development Center, Inc. under a grant from the National Science Foundation, Zoom In's key outcomes include: 

1) The Zoom In Science Website. Six highly-scaffolded online science curriculum units for high school, three in Biology and three in Earth Science.  In each standards-based Zoom In unit, students investigate a compelling scientific question by reviewing background knowledge, deeply analyzing data trends, taking notes, and writing a summary argument supported with evidence from the data.   

2) Teacher supports for teaching the units and assessing student work.  Because teaching data skills is new for science teachers, the project has created print, video and online tools that help them plan, deliver, and assess their instruction. Detailed Teacher Guides model the key teaching and discourse moves through with teachers can guide students and build their science knowledge and skill; online  assessment tools help teachers check in on student progress, and assess their final writing products.  

3) Research findings that point to the effectiveness of well-designed scaffolds for data science education, and the need for effective teacher supports in delivering data-rich instruction.  Specifically, an implementation study conducted in 11 classrooms found that students and teachers were able to use the modules with little difficulty to engage in reasoning with authentic data and science concepts. The study also identified a number of challenges teachers and students faced in incorporating these modules into their classrooms; specifically, that students need support from teachers in both making inferences about the data and in developing persuasive writing using evidence from the data. Fostering more student discussion during the modules may be one way to scaffold this kind of thinking.  The project is sharing these findings forthcoming publications for science educators, and putting lessons to work in additional data science design research projects.    

Zoom In Science is thus building bridges for both teachers and students to a future in which data science education for all is a reality in our public schools.
